title: Work-Energy theorem - changing angles of forces

content.question: At time <math alttext="t equals t sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mstyle></math>, a block is pulled to the right along a horizontal surface by a constant horizontal force <math alttext="F" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>F</mi></math> as shown in the figure. Frictional forces between the block and the surface are negligible. At time <math alttext="t equals t sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mstyle></math>, the angle <math alttext="theta" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>θ</mi></math> between the force <math alttext="F" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>F</mi></math> and the horizontal starts to increase without exceeding <math alttext="90 degrees" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>90</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">°</mi></math>, while the magnitude of the force remains constant. How does the kinetic energy of the object change as the angle increases?

choices.label: The kinetic energy remains the same.

The kinetic energy increases when <math alttext="theta is less than 45 degrees" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>θ</mi><mo><</mo><mn>45</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">°</mi></mstyle></math> and decreases when <math alttext="theta is greater than 45 degrees" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>θ</mi><mo>></mo><mn>45</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">°</mi></mstyle></math>.
